bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 30, 1947

div1.p: Hench writes that he has heard Moran plans to write his memoirs. The Cuban government is interested in preserving Building No. 1, although they have made no concrete plans.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 30, 1947
div1.opener:
April 30, 1947
General Jefferson R. Kean
2804 N Street, N. W.
Georgetown
Washington, D. C.
My dear Generals Kean and Truby:
div1.p:
I thought you would like to see a copy of a letter I have just
sent to Mr. Moran. I did not know that he was writing his memoirs. He sent
me a little note that de Kruif had sent him saying that, if his memoirs were
any good, they would find a publisher. In a day or two he wrote me that at
last the Cuban Government seemed interested in our shack. Things began to
happen fast and within a couple of days various officials asked him to show
them our shack. He had his photograph taken with these officials at
Camp Lazear and it was decided that the Government would make the shack a
National monument. A day or two later officials of the Cuban Medical College
came to him, not having heard of the governmental action, and wanted to do
something about the shack. They were greatly chagrined when the next day's
paper announced they had taken over the project. Meanwhile I have heard
from one of these officials, answering the letter I sent to his predecessor
two and one-half years ago and which his predecessor never answered. So far
as I can see the Cuban Government has not yet made any financial plans to
back up their action and they are inviting me now to participate in their
plans--which I shall be glad to do. Not surprisingly, the heading of the
newspaper photograph of the shack with Moran and the officials standing in
front read something as follows: “Shack Where Finlay Did His Work to Prove
the Cause of Yellow Fever Becomes National Monument.” The article therewith
was also considerably joggled and stated that the Mayo Clinic had already
given $10,000. I made it clear in 1944 when I wrote the officials (which
letter they never answered) that the Mayo Foundation had promised me up to
$10,000 contingent on the gifts of others and on the interest of the Cuban
Government. In any event, things seem to be moving.

I leave tomorrow to speak at the Meeting of the American College
of Physicians and then to give several lectures at the Army and Navy
General Hospital, Hot Springs, Arkansas. I have been made “Expert Civilian
Consultant to the Surgeon General” and will visit various army hospitals
from time to time.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alp
